history.content:
I've found from both my own experiences and advice from others far more experienced than I am (i.e. good engineers with 6+ years industry experience) that the best way to learn how to code better is to do code review with someone who is better than you. When you review their code, you'll get better because you'll see the things that they did right, and when they review yours, they'll point out things that you're doing wrong. 

Doing code review with someone who is the same skill level or worse relative to you helps too, since the same things will happen, just with less effectiveness (and you'll be learning more from mistakes than things done well).

Unfortunately, with the way that many courses are structured, this is difficult to do, since you aren't allowed to share your code with others. Because of this, I would try to take advantage of any group projects you are involved in, since you can usually share code within your group. Instead of just letting everyone merge their code and debug it later, require every patch to undergo code review before being merged (if time allows for this during class projects, sometimes you just need to get things done on time). This way, everyone gets their code critiqued (and will learn from caught mistakes), and you can learn from the code your group members write that you review. 

In addition, it's my understanding that most industry level software projects have some sort of code review process for quality control and such things. If you do an internship and work on a project that does code review, take advantage of it. You'll be working with people more experienced that you, and that (usually) means that they're better at programming; learn from them.

There are probably many other ways to improve your coding prowess, so if others on this Piazza have more advice, please add to this response!

---

I completely agree with Matt. I've found that coding with others is a great way to pick up new patterns/techniques. Also consider reading code from open-source projects -- for example, you might be curious about how ok.py or reddit work. Even better, you can submit your own contributions and get your code reviewed by the project maintainers.

children.subject: Like Allen said above, you could try contributing to open source projects on GitHub and getting your code reviewed that way. Alternatively, you could try this for code you're allowed to share: https://codereview.stackexchange.com/. I'm unsure of how useful it is, never used it myself. It just turned up from a quick google search.
Is there any website that provide free (or paid) code review? Are they worth it?

history.content:
I am currently taking CS61B and CS70. I had no programming experience before and it was a pain in CS61A. CS61B is getting better, but after the project last week I found myself really weak in keeping the code neat and clean. I am worried about this since I understand how important it is to make my code readable and debuggable. 

I usually review my own code and read some skeleton code, but I think it would be nicer to have some structured learning process...

Anyone has been there and is willing to share some insight?
history.subject: What kind of events, or mind set or classes teaches us how to make our code more organized?
